results.title: We lead the world
results.brief_description: The high incidence of tractor accidents in New Zealand and the safety precautions necessary with tractors. Proper handling of clutch and differential steering; need for guards on moving parts; keeping children away from tractors; need to know the country and take particular care on sloping ground; danger of driving a tractor with nobody near to help in case of accident.

results.title: We kept them flying
results.creator_credit: Maude Coates, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: On the way home from enrolling in the Women’s Australian Auxiliary Air Force (WAAAF) in 1941, Maude Coates learnt that the Japanese forces had just bombed Darwin. For almost 4 years, Coates worked hard and built a great sense of companionship with the other women she lived and worked with. Serving time in the Women’s Forces out of duty, Maude feels proud to have served her country and been part of history.

results.title: We interrupt this program
results.creator_credit: David Frankel, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
On April 13, 1970, Apollo 13, the 23rd manned flight into space, developed problems that threatened the lives of the astronauts on board. The complacency which had accompanied the launch and the disinterest of the general public throughout the mission until problems occurred were quickly dispelled, as every move was monitored by journalists who fed the story to a hungry audience fast becoming hooked on sensationalism. A divide was growing wider between the traditions of the intellectual press and the fast-feed emotional content of the new tabloid journalism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Frankel, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base

results.title: We have to start somewhere
results.creator_credit: Banks Noel Paton, Peter Richman and Eric Fullilove
results.brief_description: This film is about development. Focussing on the discussion group that appears in the film has a connection with the title of the film. The group covers, among other things, migrants, Aborigines and the relationships between rich and poor nations and the consequences of preaching Christianity without due reverence for other cultures. The film stresses the need for commitment to action

results.title: We have cleared the tower
results.creator_credit: Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
19 months and six unmanned flights after the Apollo 1 tragedy, Wally Schirra, Don Eisele and Walt Cunningham are set to become the first trio of American astronauts in space on Apollo 7 - their preparations followed every step of the way by a keen, young documentary crew. Noone can afford to make a mistake that might endanger the life of the mission or the lives of the men.

results.title: We grow here
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Interviews with Sicilian migrants who ended up making the lush lands of Northern Queensland their home. The men and women describe the hardship of their lives in Sicily, talk about their initial impressions on arrival in Australia and explore their sometimes ambivalent attachments to their two “homelands”.

results.title: We grew a frog
results.creator_credit: Boulton-Hawker Films, Peter Boulton and Nigel Rea
results.brief_description:
Records an activity in which children collect and rear frog spawn in a tank at their school. Covers each stage in the development of the frog, showing details not easily seen in a classroom aquarium.
Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: We Dream of Networks
results.credit_line:
Jess Johnson
Limited edition print
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: giclée print on archival quality cotton rag with four deckled edges, edition 40/50
results.brief_description:
Jess Johnson was born in Aotearoa/New Zealand in 1979, and lives and works in New York. Her drawing and installation practice is influenced by science fiction, language, culture and technology. In her drawings she depicts complex worlds that combine densely layered patterns, objects and figures within architectural settings. Johnson’s drawings are often displayed within constructed environments that act as physical portals into her speculative worlds. Her video collaborations with Simon Ward have involved translating her drawings into animated Virtual Reality, thus enabling her audience to have the simulated experience of entering the hypnotic realms depicted in her drawings. Jess Johnson’s work has been exhibited Internationally in solo exhibitions at; Jack Hanley Gallery, New York; Art Basel, Hong Kong; Nanzuka Gallery, Tokyo; Talbot Rice Gallery, Edinburgh; National Gallery of Australia; Museum of Contemporary Art, Australia; Auckland Art Gallery and Christchurch Art Gallery, New Zealand.

Jess Johnson is represented by Darren Knight Gallery, Sydney; Ivan Anthony Gallery, Auckland and Jack Hanley Gallery, New York
